citation and abbreviation of ordinances embraced in the following chapters articles and sections shall constitute and be designated as the farmington city  and may be abbreviated as the  city  or fcc and may be so cited  definitions and rules of construction in the construction of this of all ordinances of this city the following rules of construction and definitions shall be observed unless such construction or definition would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the city council unless such construction or definition would be repugnant to the context of the provisions or unless the context clearly requires otherwise generally all words and phrases shall be construed and understood according to the common and approved usage of language but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in the law shall be construed and understood according to such peculiar and appropriate meaning city the term city means the city of farmington new mexico city council or council the term city council or council means the city council of the city term  means the farmington city in section 111 references to the all additions and amendments to it computation of time unless otherwise specifically provided in computing time the first day shall be excluded and the last day included if the last day falls on a weekend the time prescribed shall be extended so as to include the whole of the following monday if the last day falls on a holiday the time prescribed shall be extended so as to include the whole of the next workday county the term county means san juan county new mexico delegation of authority whenever a provision appears in this an officer of the city to do some act or make certain inspections it is to be construed to authorize such officer to designate delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision or section expressly designate otherwise easement the term easement means a right liberty privilege or advantage without profit which the owner of one parcel of land may have in the lands of another  a right in the owner of one parcel of land by reason of such ownership to use the land of another for a special purpose not inconsistent with a general property right in the owner gender a word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms partnerships associations and corporations as well as to males in the city the term in the city or in this city means any territory within the corporate limits of this city and the police jurisdiction thereof and any other territory over which regulatory power has been conferred on the city by law except as otherwise specified joint authority words purporting to give authority to three or more officers or other persons shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such officers or other persons unless it is otherwise specifically declared law the term law means any statute ordinance or regulation promulgated by the united states the state the county the city or any agencies thereof as well as the rules and regulations of other bodies politic that may be appropriate may the term may is to be construed as being discretionary or permissive minor the term minor means the age with respect to all offenses except those involving alcoholic beverages of any person under 18 years of age month the term month means a calendar month nmsa 1978 the abbreviation nmsa 1978 means the new mexico statutes annotated 197 as amended number any word importing the singular number shall include the plural and any word importing the plural number shall include the singular oath the term oath includes an affirmation in all cases in which by law an affirmation may be substituted for an oath and in such cases the terms swear and sworn are equivalent to the terms affirm and affirmed official time standard whenever certain hours are named in this they shall mean standard time or daylight saving time as may be in current use in the city officials employees boards commissions etc whenever reference is made to officials employees boards commissions or other agencies of the city by title only ie mayor clerk manager chief of police etc it shall be deemed to refer to the officials employees boards commissions or other agencies of this city or and the term or may be read and and the term and may be read or if the context of the provision requires it owner the term owner when applied to a building or land includes any part owner joint owner tenant in common tenant in partnership joint tenant or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land person the term person includes any firm partnership association corporation organization club society group acting as a unit or body politic and corporate as well as to an individual personal property the term personal property includes money goods chattels evidences of debt things in action and any other species of property except real property preceding following the terms preceding and following mean next before and next after respectively property the term property includes real personal and mixed property public place the term public place means any public way park cemetery school yard or open space adjacent thereto  any public lake or stream  and any place or business open to the use of the public in general open to public view or to which the public has access public way the term public way means any street alley boulevard parkway highway sidewalk or other public thoroughfare real property the term real property includes lands tenements and hereditaments reasonable time in all cases where any section of this a city ordinance shall require any act to be done in a reasonable time or shall require reasonable notice to be given such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary for the prompt performance of such duty or compliance with such notice residence the term residence means the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation and to which whenever he is absent he has the intention of returning when a person eats at one place and sleeps at another the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence roadway the term roadway means that portion of a street improved designed or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic shall the term shall is to be construed as being mandatory sidewalk the term sidewalk means any portion of the street between the curb or the lateral line of the roadway and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians signature subscription the term signature or subscription includes a mark when the person cannot write when his name is written near such mark and is witnessed by a person who writes his own name as witness state the term state means the state of new mexico street the term street includes public streets avenues boulevards highways roads alleys lanes viaducts bridges public ways and approaches thereto and other public thoroughfares in the city devoted to public use tenant occupant the terms tenant and occupant when applied to a building or land mean any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land whether alone or with others tense words used in the past or present tense shall include the future as well as the past or present writing written the terms writing and written include typewriting printing on paper and any other mode of representing words and letters year the term year means a calendar year  catchlines of sections  history notes  references in a the catchlines of the several sections of this set in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections nor as any part of such sections nor unless expressly so provided shall they be so deemed when any of such sections including the catchlines are amended or reenacted b the history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in this not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to indicate the sources of matter contained in the section cross references editors notes and state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the user of this have no legal effect c all references to chapters articles divisions or sections are to the chapters articles divisions and sections of this unless otherwise specified  continuation of existing ordinances the provisions appearing in this so far as they are the same in substance as ordinances existing at the effective date of this shall be considered as continuations thereof and not as new enactments effect of repeal of ordinance the repeal of an ordinance or any portion thereof shall not revive any ordinance in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect the repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect nor any suit prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed  police power extended to city property the police power of the city is extended to include all lands or property owned or leased by the city or any agency of the city and the general ordinances of the city shall be applicable on such property altering shall be unlawful for any person to change or amend by additions or deletions any part or portion of this to insert or delete pages or portions thereof or to alter or tamper with such any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city to be misrepresented thereby  provided that supplementation of this authorized persons shall be permitted amendments to   effect of new this   supplementation of a by contract or by city personnel supplements to this be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the city council a supplement to the include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances passed by the city council or adopted by initiative and referendum during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the the period the pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the will where necessary replace pages that have become obsolete or partially obsolete and the new pages shall be so prepared that when they have been inserted the be current date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement b in preparing a supplement to this all portions of the have been repealed shall be excluded from the the omission thereof from reprinted pages c when preparing a supplement to this the codifier meaning the person agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement may make formal nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified code for example the codifier may 1 organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions  2 provide appropriate catchlines headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the in the supplement and make changes in such catchlines headings and titles  3 assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the where necessary to accommodate new material change existing section or other subdivision numbers  4 change the words this ordinance or words of the same meaning to this chapter this article this division etc as the case may be or to sections _____ to _____ inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the   and 5 make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the   but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the   general penalty  additional fees  additional penalties for certain acts a general penalty whenever in this in any other ordinance or resolution of the city or in any rule regulation or order promulgated by an officer or agency of the city under authority duly vested in him or if any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor where no specific penalty is provided therefor the violation of any such provision of such any other ordinance or resolution of the city or such rule regulation or order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $50000 or imprisonment for a term not exceeding 90 days or by both such fine and imprisonment except where otherwise provided every day any violation of this any other ordinance or resolution of the city or such rule regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense b correction fee assessment the municipal judge shall collect a correction fee assessment in the sum of $2000 from any person convicted of violating any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle or convicted of any ordinance which may be enforced by the imposition of a term of imprisonment no correction fee will be collected for any violation involving the unlawful parking of a motor vehicle all money collected pursuant to this subsection shall be deposited in a special fund in the municipal treasury and shall be used for such purposes as provided by state law as from time to time amended c penalty for driving while under influence of alcohol or drug as used in this subsection the term conviction means a finding of guilt of any provision of federal state or local law forbidding driving while under the influence of any alcohol or drug or driving with a blood alcohol content in excess of a specified minimum in addition to any provision of the state motor vehicle code or this the following penalties shall apply to violations of sections 2511668102 and 251166539 1 upon a first conviction of this offense the minimum punishment shall be imprisonment for 72 consecutive hours 2 upon a second or third conviction of section 2511668102 or any violation of section 251166539 the offender shall be punished by a term of imprisonment of not more than 179 days 3 upon a first conviction for aggravated driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs pursuant to sections 2511668102 or any second or third conviction for driving while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or drugs the municipal court shall as a condition of probation require the offender to have an ignition interlock device installed and operating for a period of at least one year on all motor vehicles driven by the offender pursuant to rules adopted by the new mexico traffic safety bureau unless determined by the municipal court to be indigent the offender shall pay all costs associated with having an interlock device installed on the appropriate vehicles in no event shall the city be responsible for any of the costs associated with the installation or operation of the ignition interlock device if an offender drives a motor vehicle that does not have an ignition interlock device installed the offender shall be in violation of the terms and conditions of his probation 4 in all other cases municipal court may order an interlock device to be installed on all motor vehicles to be driven by the offender upon the same terms as set forth in the preceding section d maximum imprisonment for more than one offense in single occurrence notwithstanding any other section of this state law when a defendant is charged with more than one offense arising out of a single transaction act or occurrence the maximum sentence of imprisonment that may be imposed shall not be greater than 179 days e fine for violation of wastewater pretreatment ordinances notwithstanding the general penalty in subsection a of this section upon conviction of any violation of an ordinance relating to wastewater pretreatment the municipal court shall impose a fine of not more than $100000 per day for each violation f court automation fee in addition to any fine or imprisonment there is imposed upon any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance the penalty for which carries a potential jail term or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle a mandatory court automation fee of $600 all court automation fees collected shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the municipal court automation fund and shall be used for the purchase and maintenance of court automation systems in the municipal courts the court automation systems shall have the capability of providing on a timely basis electronic records in a format specified by the judicial information system council g fee for tests for person convicted of marijuana possession a person convicted of possession of marijuana in violation of section 1859 shall be assessed in addition to any other fine or fee a fee of $7500 to defray the costs of chemical and other tests utilized h judicial education fee any person convicted of violating any municipal ordinance the penalty for which carries a potential jail term or any ordinance relating to the operation of a motor vehicle shall pay to the municipal court in addition to any fine or other sentence a judicial education fee in the amount established by state law all money collected pursuant to this subsection shall be remitted monthly to the state treasurer for credit to the judicial education fund and shall be used for such purposes as provided by state law as ch 26 article 1  in general city seal the impression of the city seal is as follows in the center the words incorporated seal 1901 and around the outer edge the words city of farmington new mexico  article 2  city council footnotes  2  cross reference disaster succession  1031 et seq state law reference governing body of municipalities nmsa 197  3121 et seq division 1  generally composition subject to the provisions of this article pertaining to the implementation of districting the governing body of the city shall consist of a mayor to be elected at large and four councilors who shall be elected from singlemember districts  state law reference election of members of governing bodies from singlemember districts nmsa 197  31211 salary of mayor and councilors the mayor shall receive an annual salary of $1500000 councilors shall receive an annual salary of $1000000 the salaries of the mayor and the councilors shall be paid periodically to correspond with the usual pay periods of the city  state law reference salaries of mayor and councilmen nmsa 197  3103 44441 secs 2232230  reserved division 2  election creation of districts a councilors shall reside in and shall be elected from singlemember municipal election districts b the boundaries of each municipal election district are shown on the municipal election district map as adopted or as may be amended as provided in section 2232 1 amendment of district map a pursuant to the requirements of nmsa 197  31211 the city council shall divide the city into four districts equal to the number of members in the city council each district shall be compact and contiguous and composed of populations as nearly equal as possible b pursuant to the requirements of nmsa 197  3122f the city council may redistrict the city whenever redistricting is warranted upon receipt of a petition signed by qualified electors equal in number to the votes cast for a councilor receiving the greatest number of votes at the last regular municipal election the city council shall redistrict the city c pursuant to the requirements of nmsa 197  31211 the city council shall redistrict the city following every federal decennial census d the city council may whenever it may deem districting to be warranted amend the municipal election district map e changes in boundaries of the municipal election district map shall be noted on the official municipal election district map kept on file and in the custody of the city clerk f changes made upon the official municipal election district map shall be commemorated by resolution adopted by the city council and shall be effective immediately upon adoption of the resolution g the city clerk shall give notice of the proposed adoption of a commemorative resolution described in subsection f of this section by publication of the proposed resolution or a summary thereof in a newspaper of general circulation in the city not less than ten days prior to the adoption of such resolution provided that the city council may adopt such resolution as an emergency measure without such publication if it determines that an emergency exists which requires adoption of the resolution without notice and publication 2 candidates a only persons residing in a particular municipal election district and who otherwise meet all applicable requirements imposed by law or ordinance shall be allowed to be candidates for the position of councilor for that municipal election district b in determining whether the residence of a person is in a particular district the rules set forth in nmsa 197  383 and 117 shall apply c in addition to the requirements for a declaration of candidacy set forth in nmsa 197  3827a the city clerk shall not accept a declaration of candidacy for the position of councilor unless the declaration of candidacy states which district the candidate resides in and is seeking election from the city clerk shall determine if the candidates residence is within the district from which the candidate is seeking election if the candidate does not reside within the district the city clerk shall determine that the declaration of candidacy is invalid d a writein candidate shall not be elected to fill the position of councilor unless the writein candidate resides in the district from which the writein candidate is elected 4 contents of resolution in addition to the requirements of nmsa 197  3826 the election resolution calling for the regular municipal election shall set forth which districts of the city will be electing councilors 5 polling places in addition to the requirements of nmsa 197  3811 the city council shall ensure that each election district has not less than one polling place 6 ballots in addition to the requirements of nmsa 197  3829 the city clerk shall cause all ballots to separate candidates for the position of councilor by district the order of the candidates running for office within each district shall be determined by a drawing by lot there shall be a position for a voter to insert a writein candidate below the names of the candidates running for legislative office from each district 7 duties of precinct boards in addition to the requirements of nmsa 197  3820 the precinct board shall ensure that each person who votes is registered in the district resides in the district is otherwise a qualified elector and votes only for a candidate for the position of councilor from the district 8 publication of names of candidates in addition to the requirements of nmsa 197  3830 the city clerk shall ensure that the publication of the names of candidates for the office of councilor shall designate from which election district each such candidate is seeking election 9 election of other municipal officers nothing in this division shall be construed to affect the manner in which other municipal officers are elected 10 plurality of votes required for election in addition to the requirements of nmsa 197  3832 each candidate for the position of councilor shall only receive votes cast for such candidate by the resident qualified electors of the election district from which that candidate is running the candidate who receives a plurality of votes cast in that district shall be elected to the office for the term designated 11 canvass of returns  certificates regarding canvass of returns and issuance of an election certificate appropriate election officials shall ensure that returns are canvassed and election certificates are issued on a districtbydistrict basis for the position of councilor 12 adoption and implementation of procedures the city clerk shall adopt and implement appropriate procedures to ensure that elections conducted under supervision of the clerk are conducted in a fair and impartial manner that only qualified voters are allowed to vote upon candidates or questions which are at large and that district voters vote only in the district in which such voters reside and are qualified 13 division 3  campaign financing definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this division shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning candidate means an individual seeking election to the position of mayor councilor or municipal judge at a regular or special election of the city contribution means a gift subscription loan advance or deposit of any money or other thing of value which is made for the primary purpose of supporting or opposing a candidate for elective office this does not include the value of a volunteers time provided without compensation or unreimbursed personal expenses such as vehicle use or meals of individuals who volunteer a portion or all of their time on behalf of a candidate election means any regular or special municipal election in the city expenditure means a payment transfer or distribution or obligation or promise to pay transfer or distribute any money or other thing of value for the purpose of influencing the outcome of an election of a candidate but does not include the candidates or his immediate familys personal expenses such as vehicle use or meals general purpose political committee means a political committee other than a special purpose political committee political committee means every two or more persons who are selected appointed chosen or associated for the purpose of wholly or in part supporting or opposing a candidate at any election and includes political committees or similar organizations composed of employees or members of any corporation labor organization trade or professional association or any other similar group which raises collects expends or contributes money or any other thing of value for the purpose of supporting or opposing a candidate in a municipal election reporting individual means every candidate every treasurer of every special purpose political committee or treasurer of every general purpose political committee whose purpose is to aid the candidate in the campaign for municipal office special purpose political committee means a political committee making contributions to support or oppose one candidate such contributions being limited to one special or one regular election  7913 applicability of division this division also applies to any contributions expenditures persons or committees whose purpose is to encourage adoption or defeat of any municipal question submitted to the voters of the city  7913 paid political ads no candidate or political committee shall pay all or any part of the cost of a political ad endorsing a candidate for an election without disclosing such sponsorship in the ad  7913 reports required each candidate and each treasurer of each special purpose political committee and general purpose political committee shall file with the city clerk a report of expenditures and contributions on forms prescribed by the city clerk when the reporting individual is a candidate the report shall include the expenditures and contributions of those political committees authorized by the candidate to expend and receive funds on behalf of his candidacy and when the candidate files a report for the political committee the treasurer thereof need not file a report of expenditures and contributions for the period of time covered in the candidates report  7913 forms furnished by city the city clerk shall furnish upon request to political committees or candidates the form for the reporting of expenditures and contributions the clerk shall give each candidate or a designated representative the prescribed reporting forms at the time of filing the declaration of candidacy approximately ten days before any report of expenditures and contributions is required to be filed by this division the city clerk shall send each candidate by mail or email a reminder of the deadline for filing the report  7913 contents under this division each reporting individual shall file a report containing the following information 1 a report of expenditures and contributions itemizing each item of expenditure and contribution including a the name and address of the person or business to whom an expenditure was made or from whom a contribution was received  b the amount of the expenditure or contribution or value thereof  c a description of the inkind services or goods received  and d the date of the expenditure or contribution 2 the report shall include all contributions received and expenditures made which have not been previously reported regardless of when received or made and even if received or made before the candidate filed a declaration of candidacy  and 3 the report of expenditures and contributions shall be subscribed and sworn to by the candidate or treasurer of the political committee as the case may be  7913 time for filing all candidates and special purpose political committees and general purpose political committees shall file reports of expenditures and contributions for the following reporting periods 1 during the year where the candidate is running for election a report shall be filed by  pm on the following dates a the first monday following candidate filing day  b the second monday of february  c the thursday before the election  d the date which is 30 days after an election unless that date is a weekend or a holiday and then on the next regular business day  e the second monday of october 2 during any year in which the candidate did not run in an election a report shall be filed by  pm on the second monday of each october unless the candidate or committee neither received nor expended campaign funds since the last report was filed  7913   41117  late filing penalty if any candidate or treasurer of a political committee files a report of expenditures and contributions after any deadline imposed by the campaign procedures such person shall be liable and shall pay to the city clerk at the time of late filing the sum of $5000 per day for each regular working day after the time required by this division for the filing of reports of expenditures and contributions an incomplete report will be considered as no report  a late filing penalty will apply to the completed report if it is not filed within the prescribed time limits all sums collected for such penalty shall be deposited in the general fund of the city if sent by certified mail or registered mail the report shall be deemed filed on the date three days following the date of the postmark  7913 failure to file report any candidate who fails or refuses to file a report of expenditures and contributions in the manner and within the time required by this division shall not be issued a certificate of election until such candidate files the report of expenditures and contributions  7913 political committee treasurer it is unlawful for the members of any political committee or candidate to make any expenditure or solicit or accept any contribution for the purpose of supporting or opposing a candidate unless 1 a treasurer has been appointed and is constantly maintained  however when a duly appointed treasurer is unable for any reason to continue as treasurer the candidate may appoint a successor provided that nothing in this subsection prohibits a candidate from appointing himself treasurer  2 all disbursements of money and receipts of contributions shall be recorded by and treasurer  and 3 such treasurer upon disbursing or receiving money or other things of value shall immediately enter and thereafter keep in a proper book to be preserved by him a full true and itemized statement and account of each sum disbursed or received the date of such disbursal or receipt to whom disbursed or from whom received and the object and purpose for which it has been disbursed or received  7913 contribution limitations a total contributions to any candidates campaign for any municipal office by any individual or business entity shall not exceed $230000 per election total contributions to any candidates campaign for any municipal office by any political committee shall not exceed $500000 per election b anonymous contributions are prohibited and a candidate may not knowingly accept or use a contribution without disclosing the source of the contribution on the candidates reports if a candidate comes into possession of an attempted anonymous contribution it shall not be used for campaign purposes but shall be contributed to a charitable organization of the candidates choice c a candidate may contribute to the candidates own campaign without regard to the limitations in paragraph a of this section as long as those contributions and the expenses they are used to pay for are reported on the reports required in sections 2246 of this division  7913 election financial records a candidates for elective office or treasurers for political committees shall keep financial records for a period of six months following the date of election in order that the records will be available if a complaint is filed or inquiry is made such financial records shall include cancelled checks invoices receipts bank statements bills of sale statements of account and all other financial records pertinent to the campaign b in preparing and maintaining financial records such as ledgers and journals and recording contributions and expenditures on the disclosure statement of campaign financing the candidates or treasurers of political committees shall 1 record inkind contributions as both contributions and expenditures with a description of such inkind services or goods received  2 record campaign loans as contributions with subsequent repayment of loans credited against contributions  and 3 record returned contributions as credits against contributors c the services of a person who is performing the duties of treasurer pursuant to this division shall review board established  terms  organization  purpose a the administrative review board is established which shall consist of five members each of whom shall be a resident of the city appointed by the mayor subject to the approval of the city council b members of the administrative review board may be appointed from professional and occupational groups within the city which will provide administrative legal and technical expertise in the areas that fall within the jurisdiction of the administrative review board c members of the administrative review board shall serve staggered terms of two years each d members shall serve at the pleasure of the mayor and may be removed at the pleasure of the mayor subject to the approval of the city council e a vacancy occurring in the membership of the administrative review board shall be filled as soon as is reasonably possible by appointment by the mayor and confirmation by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member f staff support services for the administrative review board shall be provided by the community development department and by such other departments as may be designated by the city manager g the purpose of the administrative review board shall be to administratively determine certain matters of city business which are of a factfinding rather than a legislative nature  chair the administrative review board shall elect a chair from its members to serve for a term of one year with eligibility for reelection  meetings generally  rules of procedure  records the administrative review board shall hold at least one regular meeting a month  shall adopt rules for transaction of its business  and shall record its resolutions transactions findings and determinations which shall be a matter of public record all meetings of the administrative review board shall be open to the public and notice thereof shall be given in the manner provided by law  quorum a the administrative review board may conduct an official meeting with a quorum of three members present a majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for transaction of business b since decisionmaking authority is delegated to the administrative review board alternate members at large shall not be appointed pursuant to section 241  technical assistance the administrative review board may in its discretion seek any technical assistance it may require in the performance of its duties it may subject to the administrative supervisory control of the city manager request the assistance of any city department or official including the code compliance officer or any department head upon any matter brought before it or may in its discretion request the advice and assistance of members of the community who are qualified by experience and training with reference to any particular matter before it however the board shall incur no expense for such assistance unless such expense is approved by the city council  authority the administrative review board is delegated authority to carry out the functions and duties delegated to it and to the extent of such duty is designated as a planning authority pursuant to nmsa 197  3211 et seq  a zoning authority to hear appeals under nmsa 197  3211 et seq  a board of appeals under the provisions of the uniform fire   and a board of appeals as defined in the uniform building  findings and determination of council for the purpose of this division the city council does find and determine that 1 due to the rapid expansion and development of the city there is an ever increasing number of requests for variances from this an increasing number of appeals from decisions of various city inspectors and officials rendered in the enforcement or interpretation of various sections of this rendered in the determination of the manner in which various should be applied 2 an inordinate amount of the time is being spent by the fire prevention bureau the planning and zoning commission and the city council in the factfinding process which is necessary to resolve requests for variances and to determine appeals from the decisions of various city officials 3 it is desirable economically sound efficient and otherwise in the best interests of the city for the city to establish the administrative review board to hear and determine such variances and appeals subject to the right of appeal to the city council 4 it is further determined that time and energy of members of the planning and zoning commission and the fire prevention bureau should not be spent in the determination of variances and administrative review but that the time of such members should be spent in advising the city council upon policy and legislative matters  jurisdiction the administrative review board shall subject to the right of appeal to the city council have jurisdiction to determine variances and to hear and decide appeals which pertain to 1 the uniform fire the life safety   2 the city building code  3 the city plumbing code  4 the garbage and sanitation ordinances  5 the zoning ordinances  6 denial or revocation of business licenses or business registrations  7 the flood damage prevention ordinance  and 8 any other matter which may be referred to it by the city council  duties it shall be the duty of the administrative review board to 1 hear and determine all requests for variances within its jurisdiction 2 hear and determine subject to appeal to the city council the complaint of any person aggrieved by any decision of the building inspector or an administrative officer commission committee or bureau in the enforcement or the interpretation of the codes ordinances rules or regulations within the boards jurisdiction 3 investigate and return findings and recommendations upon any other issue the city council may refer to it for decision  procedures a any person aggrieved including any city officer department board or official affected by any decision of the building inspector or an administrative officer commission committee or bureau in the enforcement or interpretation of the provisions of this an ordinance a rule or a regulation within the jurisdiction of the administrative review board may appeal to the administrative review board b any such appeal shall be taken within 30 days after the decision of the building inspector code compliance officer building official fire prevention enforcement officer sanitation officer or other administrative officer has been rendered and the appeal shall be in such form as may be prescribed by the rules of the board failure to appeal within such 30day period shall bar an appeal unless such requirement shall be waived by the administrative review board or by the city council c the appeal shall be filed with the community development department or with such other department as may be designated by the city manager shall contain a notice of appeal and shall specify the grounds of the appeal d a copy of the appeal and the notice shall be sent to the building inspector code compliance officer or other official who has rendered such decision and a copy shall also be sent to the city attorney and the particular city department involved in the decision the community development department or the department designated by the city manager to furnish staff support for the appeal shall consult with the legal department and upon the advice and instruction of the legal department give notice to other persons or property owners who may be interested parties as determined by the legal department notice of any request for a variance from any section of this the jurisdiction of the administrative review board or any appeal related to a section of the unified development be sent to the owners of adjoining property pursuant to the procedure outlined in the unified development e upon receipt of a notice of appeal the building inspector code compliance officer or other official enforcing or interpreting the appropriate shall forthwith transmit to the community development department or the department designated by the city manager to furnish staff support for the appeal all papers pertaining to the cause together with a summary of all pertinent facts which constitute the record upon which the action appealed from is taken f an appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the appropriate city official charged with the enforcement of the particular certifies to the administrative review board after the notice of appeal has been sent to him that because of the facts stated in the certificate a stay would in his opinion cause imminent peril to life or property in such a case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by the city council or a court of record on application or notice to the particular official involved and on due cause shown g the community development department or the department designated by the city manager to furnish staff support for the appeal in cooperation with the administrative review board and the parties affected upon receipt of all papers constituting the record upon which the action taken was appealed from shall fix a time for hearing within 30 days of receipt of such record and shall give due notice thereof h the administrative review board shall conduct a hearing upon the matter and within ten days after such hearing render its decision which shall be supported by a statement of the issues presented by the appeal and which shall include findings of fact and reasons in support of such decision i each member of the administrative review board may separately state his views or objections upon the subject before the administrative review board and may make findings and issue reasons in support thereof j copies of the written decision of the administrative review board shall forthwith be sent to the party filing the appeal the appropriate city officials the office of the city attorney the department head of the department which is involved the city manager the mayor and each of the city councilors the decision of the administrative review board shall be final unless within 15 days from the date such decision is rendered the party shall appeal such decision in writing to the city council or unless not less than two members of the city council issue instructions in writing to the administrative review board directing that such matter be forwarded to the city council for further review k any person may appear in person or by attorney before the administrative review board to be heard and to present evidence bearing upon such appeal    schedule of fees the city council may by resolution provide for a schedule of reasonable fees to be paid for filing and pursuing an appeal to the administrative review board and to the city council all such fees shall bear a reasonable relation to the expense involved for processing such appeal the resolution may also in the discretion of the city council allow for a refund of such fee if an appellant is successful if the city is or its officers or employees are found to be at fault or for other equitable reasons  appeal to city council if any appeal is presented to or brought forth to the city council as provided in this division the city council shall hear the appeal as part of regular city business and shall render its decision which shall include findings of fact and reasons in support thereof which shall be reflected in the official city minutes the decision of the administrative review board shall not be reversed modified amended or otherwise decided except by a vote of three councilors any councilor may separately state his views or objections to the findings of the council which shall also be incorporated in the official city minutes  appeal to district court any person aggrieved by a decision of the city council pursuant to this division may appeal to the district court within 30 days of the date of the decision rendered by the city council  jurisdiction of courts not affected this division shall not be construed as any limitation upon the power of the courts or as a limitation upon the right of any person to file a complaint for violation of any section of this any city ordinance in the municipal court or as any limitation upon the authority of the court to impose a fine or jail sentence upon conviction in the municipal court for violation of this any applicable city pertaining specifically to the operation of the water and sewer utility system however nothing in this section shall empower the board to deal directly in the affairs of management but it shall confine its action to recommendations of policy to the city council the mayor and the city manager  particular duties the board of public utility commissioners shall have the following particular duties 1 rules and regulations of electric utility system subject to the approval and adoption of such rules and regulations by the city council the board shall recommend general rules and policies of the municipal electric utility system in making any such recommendations for the municipal electric utility system the board shall recommend uniform rules and regulations for the entire municipal electric utility system which shall conform to the state laws relating to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under the public utility act of new mexico insofar as the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under such public utility act attaches to the operation of the municipal electric utility system in the area of operations beyond a distance of five miles from the corporate limits of the city 2 rules and regulations of water utility system subject to the approval of the city council the board shall recommend general rules and policies of the municipal water utility system 3 rules and regulations of sewer utility system subject to the approval of the city council the board shall recommend general rules and policies of the municipal sewer utility system 4 rates and conditions of service subject to the approval and adoption of such rates and service conditions by the city council the board shall recommend rates and charges for electric power and energy water or sewer utility service furnished by the municipal electric water and sewer utility systems and shall recommend conditions of service applicable to the furnishing of such electric power and energy water or sewer service in making any such recommendations for the municipal electric utility system the board shall recommend uniform rates and service conditions for the entire municipal electric utility system which conform to the state laws relating to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under the public utility act of new mexico insofar as the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under such public utility act attaches to the operation of the municipal electric utility system in the area of operations beyond a distance of five miles from the corporate limits of the city 5 line extension policies subject to the approval and adoption of such line extension policy by the city council the board shall recommend line extension policies to be followed by the municipal electric utility system and extension policies for municipal water and sewer utility services in making any such recommendations for the municipal electric utility system the board shall recommend uniform line extension policies which shall conform to the requirements of the state laws relating to the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under the public utility act of new mexico insofar as the jurisdiction of the state public service commission under such public utility act attaches to the operation of the municipal electric utility system in the area of operations beyond a distance of five miles from the corporate limits of the city 6 changes in rules regulations conditions of service and line extension policies no rule or regulation rate or condition of service or line extension policy having been adopted and approved by the city council shall be amended modified abrogated repealed or otherwise changed by the board without the approval of the city council and in conformity with law 7 contracts for service generally subject to the supervening power of the city council to authorize the execution of all contracts by the city which water or sewer utility systems or otherwise shall be executed by the city the board shall recommend all forms of contracts relating to service to be provided by the municipal electric water and sewer utility systems or any special contracts relating to service to be furnished by the municipal electric water and sewer utility systems at special contract rates or relating to line extensions when electric utility water and sewer utility systems 9 annual budgets the board may and when so directed by the council shall prepare and recommend an annual budget for the municipal electric utility creation the community relations commission of the city of farmington is hereby created  12807 mission the mission statement of the community relations commission is to promote ways in which our community can value and safeguard equal opportunity for all  12807 purpose the purpose of the community relations commission shall be to set standards for positive community relations dealing with cultural diversity fairness integrity and respect to all people the commission will encourage and promote mutual self respect and understanding of each other by all citizens and groups in the city the commission will function with integrity fairness and respect to all  12807 duties the community relations commission is an advisory commission only whose recommendations shall not be binding upon the city it shall be the duty and responsibility of the community relations commission to 1 establish a procedure for receiving and reviewing complaints compliments and feedback that includes fact gathering seeking legal guidance acquiring information for investigation of an issue and providing bilingual resources as necessary 2 provide and conduct mediation or to offer referrals if necessary 3 advise the city council and city administration on problems of local interest group relations and to assist advise and inform the citizens of important related issues and projects 4 act as liaison between the city and other professional business government and civic organizations in order to improve communication and cooperate and coordinate efforts to improve working relationships with such groups in the area of cultural diversity fairness mutual respect and understanding 5 manage statistical data related to the commissions duties 6 develop and provide educational programs orientation and training including but not limited to ways to improve communication understanding and cooperation between all citizens and groups throughout the area 7 assist with and provide marketing to express the commissions mission and purpose to the public 8 sponsorship of events 9 provide information to the media as necessary 10 dissemination of brochures pamphlets publications reports and statistical data as in its judgment will tend to promote the commissions mission statement and eliminate group tensions and prejudices 11 implementation of award and incentive programs 12 foster mutual understanding and respect among all groups and organizations of the city regardless of race religion or beliefs 13 advise the community on methods to promote mutual understanding and respect among all citizens 14 work to assure equal opportunities for all within the community and to develop ways to relieve community tensions arising from cultural or group differences  12807 membership  term of office the community relations commission shall consist of nine voting members and six ex officio nonvoting members all of whom shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the council every effort will be made to include representatives from each council district and a majority of all of the members both voting and non voting should live within the city limits of farmington the membership will be diversified based on ethnicity age disability gender and occupation the nine voting members will serve staggered terms with five of the members being appointed initially to threeyear terms and four of the members being appointed to twoyear terms thereafter members shall serve twoyear terms a members term is limited to four consecutive terms  12807 officers the community relations commission shall elect a chairperson a chairperson pro tem  and unless the city manager has designated a city employee to serve in such capacity shall elect one member to serve as secretary to record the minutes of the meeting of the commission  12807 meetings the community relations commission shall hold a regular meeting once per month and special meetings as needed notice of meetings should be published and advertised to the public and media as provided in the citys open meetings policy agendas will be available to the public in advance of the meeting as required by law  12807 quorum a quorum for a meeting of the community relations commission shall consist of five voting members a majority vote of such quorum shall suffice for the transaction of business  12807 compensation the members of the community relations commission shall be paid no salary for their services as members of the commission  however the members shall be entitled to per diem and mileage authorized by law when out of town on city business  12807 removal members serve at the will of the mayor and the city council and may be removed at any time by the mayor subject to the confirmation of the city council unless extenuating circumstances are presented to the mayor in advance for approval any member who misses three consecutive meetings or more than 50 percent of the meetings in any running twelvemonth period shall be removed from the commission and replaced according to the procedures set out in section 24165  12807 vacancies vacancies occurring in membership of the commission shall be filled by appointment of the mayor and confirmed by the city council for the remainder of the unexpired term of such member  12807 recommendations and reports the commission may consider such matters and issues as requested by the city manager or city council and may report back their findings and recommendations to the city manager upon receiving a recommendation from the commission the city manager will promptly schedule such recommendation on an upcoming agenda to be heard by the city council the commission shall submit annually a written report of its activities and an evaluation of the effectiveness of the commission to the city council and mayor with recommendations for changes  12807 secs 2416724180  reserved division 7  planning and zoning commission footnotes  12  editors parked aircraft from free and unobstructed movement if it becomes necessary to move any one parked aircraft due to any emergency the intent of this subsection is to ensure that only one parked aircraft may be easily moved away from its position without first moving other parked aircraft this subsection shall not apply to the parking of aircraft in an aircraft hangar building  operators conduct when tower not in operation a all aircraft operated from or upon the four corners regional airport when the tower is not in operation at the airport shall be operated in accordance with the rules of section 331 except as follows 1 the appropriate radio tower frequency shall be monitored at all times by twoway radio to determine the location of other airport traffic aircraft operators shall announce on the tower frequency or appropriate frequency designated by the airport manager aircraft position at takeoff position downwind and position of final approach to landing even though the tower is not in operation to alert other aircraft to traffic 2 aircraft awaiting takeoff shall park so as to have a direct view of aircraft approaching for landing and shall park at least 100 feet from the runway in use or short of markings placed upon the runway to indicate the area to be used for awaiting takeoff b taxiing shall conform to taxi charts that are on file in the office of the airport manager and the city clerk c all aircraft takeoffs and landings by the pilot shall be in the direction indicated by the airport wind direction indicator d no turns shall be made after takeoff until the airport boundary has been reached and the aircraft has attained an altitude of at least 400 feet and it has been ascertained that there will be no danger of collision with other aircraft e aircraft intending to remain in the traffic pattern shall continue to climb to traffic pattern altitude after the first 90degree turn the direction of aerial traffic when the tower is not operating around the outside of the four corners regional airport shall be counterclockwise while at or below 1500 feet above the surface of the airport and within a threemile radius of the airport f the pilot of any transport category aircraft and other aircraft of similar size shall enter the traffic pattern when the airport tower is not operating at 1500 feet above the surface of the airport or at such higher altitude appropriate for high speed aircraft and shall maintain that altitude until in position to begin descent for landing g any pilot of smaller aircraft when the tower is not operating shall enter the traffic pattern at an altitude of 1000 feet above the surface when at least three miles from the airport and shall maintain that altitude until in position to begin descent for landing  article 4  motor vehicles footnotes  3  cross reference traffic and vehicles ch 25 operation generally at the airport no person shall 1 operate any motor vehicle or mobile equipment other than equipment 4 at night operate any motor vehicle or motorized ground equipment on any apron ramp taxiway or the landing area unless such vehicle or equipment has lights turned on which are clearly airport manager and if not in conflict with this chapter shall also apply to operation of motor vehicles on the airport b all authorized vehicles traversing traffic movement areas other than service areas ie ramps fueling areas passenger loading areas etc of the air operations area proper without twoway radio shall display and fly on the rear of the vehicle a checkered flag of a size not less than three feet square twoway radio communications between the tower and all ground vehicles operating on usable runways and taxiways will be maintained at all times escort vehicles with twoway communications capability with the tower are to accompany maintenance or service vehicles without twoway radio communications capability when operating on traffic movement areas before crossing any runway all vehicles will first obtain permission to cross such runway from the control tower by radio upon receiving clearance the driver will ensure by personal observation that no aircraft is approaching his position vehicles that do not obtain proper clearance will be reported to the airport manager by the control tower c during the hours of darkness no vehicle shall cross a lighted runway unless specific clearance is obtained from the control tower either by radio communications or lightgun signal the operator of a vehicle without a radio will first call the control tower by phone to obtain recognition by the tower while at a taxiway holding line the driver will flash the vehicle headlights toward the tower and proceed across only upon a light signal from the tower d emergency conditions existing at any time on the airport will not mitigate or cancel the regulations of this section during such conditions the driver of any vehicle will make certain that he does not move his vehicle in any direction unless specifically cleared by the control tower to do so e all vehicles operating in the airport operations area must be equipped with twoway radios and be in continuous communication with the control tower with the exception of the following equipment which will be accompanied by an escort vehicle when operating or working on usable runways or taxiways 1 crash equipment while attending an accident 2 refueling vehicles and towing tugs must cross aircraft areas for loading purposes only prior to crossing the operator must obtain clearance from the control tower 3 operational agricultural and maintenance equipment operators not engaged in working on runway property will keep the control tower informed of the general area in which the equipment is working 4 any vehicle crossing any taxiway or runway and not equipped with a twoway radio and in direct contact with the control tower shall not be operated within the landing area until prior permission is received from the tower and then the operator must observe all light signals from the tower f the installation of twoway radios does not permit the operation of vehicles on the airport without prior permission from the airport manager and the control tower g any vehicle that has been permitted to operate on the airport will not proceed closer than 200 feet from the edge of the runways or across any of the runways prior to being cleared by the tower it is the responsibility of all vehicle operators to be familiar with the standard airport light signals regardless of whether or not the vehicle is radio equipped  limitations of article no action taken under the authority of this article shall be interpreted as dedicating land at the airport as a public street road or highway  article 5  airport zoning footnotes  4  state law reference adoption of airport zoning regulations nmsa 197  33920 short title this article shall be known and may be cited as four corners regional airport zoning  app ii  1 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning airport means the four corners regional airport airport elevation means the established elevation of the highest point on the usable landing area which is 5502 feet mean sea level airport hazard means any structure tree or use of land which obstructs the airspace required for or which is otherwise hazardous to the flight of aircraft in landing or taking off at the airport airport reference point means the point established as the approximate geographic center of the airport landing area and is established at a location described as follows longitude 108 degrees 13 minutes and 54 seconds latitude 36 degrees 44 minutes and 30 seconds board of appeals means a board consisting of three members as provided for in height for the purpose of determining the height limits in all zones set forth in this article and shown on the zoning map means the datum which shall be mean sea level unless otherwise specified landing area means the area of the airport used for the landing takeoff or taxiing of aircraft nonconforming use means any structure tree or use of land which is lawfully in existence at the time the regulation as prescribed in this article or an amendment thereto becomes effective and does not then meet the requirements of such regulation noninstrument runway means a runway other than instrument runway runway means the paved surface of an airport landing strip structure means an object constructed or installed by man including but without limitation buildings towers smokestacks and overhead transmission lines tree means an object of natural growth app ii  2 cross reference definitions generally  112 zones in order to carry out this article there are created and established certain zones which include all of the land lying within the noninstrument approach zones transition zones horizontal zone and conical zone such areas and zones are shown on the four corners regional airport zoning map consisting of one sheet prepared by c c cash city engineer and dated  which is made a part of this article the various zones are established and defined as follows 1 noninstrument approach zones a noninstrument approach zone is established at each end of all noninstrument runways on the airport for noninstrument landing and takeoff the noninstrument approach zone shall have a width of 500 feet at a distance of 200 feet beyond each end of the runway widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 2500 feet at a distance of 10200 feet beyond each end of the runway its centerline being the continuation of a centerline of the runway 2 instrument approach zone an instrument approach zone is established at each end of all instrument runways on the airport for instrument landings and takeoffs the instrument approach zone shall have a width of 1000 feet a distance of 200 feet beyond each end of the runway widening thereafter uniformly to a width of 16000 feet at a distance of 50200 feet beyond each end of the runway its centerline being the continuation of the centerline of the runway 3 transition zones transition zones are established to each instrument and noninstrument runway and approach zone as indicated on the zoning map transition zones symmetrically located on either side of runways have variable width as shown on the zoning map transition zones extend outward from a line 250 feet noninstrument and 500 feet instrument on either side of the centerline of the noninstrument or instrument runway for the length of such runway plus 200 feet on each end and are parallel and level with such runway centerlines the transition zones along such runways slope upward and outward one foot vertically for each seven feet horizontally to the point where they intersect the surface of the horizontal zone further transition zones are established adjacent to noninstrument approach zones for the entire length of the approach zones these transition zones have variable widths as shown on the zoning map such transition zones flare symmetrically with either side of the runway approach zones from the base of such zones and slope upward and outward at the rate of one foot vertically for each seven feet horizontally to the points where they intersect the surfaces of the horizontal and conical zones 4 horizontal zone a horizontal zone is established as the area within a circle with its center at the airport reference point and having a radius of 1000 feet the horizontal zone does not include the noninstrument or instrument approach zones and the transition zones 5 conical zone a conical zone is established as the area that commences at the periphery of the horizontal zone and extends outward therefrom a distance of 5000 feet the conical zone does not include the noninstrument approach zones and transition zones app ii  3 height limitations a except as otherwise provided in this article no structure or tree shall be erected altered allowed to grow or maintained in any zone created by this article to a height in excess of the height limit established in this section for such zone such height limitations are established for each of the zones as follows 1 noninstrument approach zones one foot in height for each 40 feet in horizontal distance beginning at a point 200 feet from and at the elevation of the end of the noninstrument runway and extending to a point 10200 feet from the end of the runway 2 instrument approach zones one foot in height for each 50 feet in horizontal distance beginning at a point 200 feet from and at the elevation of the end of the instrument runway and extending to a point 10200 feet from the end of the runway  thence one foot in height for each 40 feet in horizontal distance beginning at a point 10200 feet from the end of the runway at an elevation of 200 feet above the end of the instrument runway and extending to a point 50200 feet from the end of the runway 3 transition zones one foot in height for each seven feet in horizontal distance beginning at any point 250 feet noninstrument and 500 feet instrument normal to and at the elevation of the centerline of the instrument and noninstrument runways extending 200 feet beyond each end thereof extending to a height of 150 feet above the airport elevation which is 5652 feet above the mean sea level in addition there are established height limits of one foot vertical height for each seven feet horizontal distance measured from the edges of all approach zones for the entire length of the approach zones and extending upward and outward to the points where they intersect the horizontal or conical surfaces 4 horizontal zone one hundred fifty feet above the airport elevation or a height of 5652 feet above mean sea level 5 conical zone one foot in height for each 20 feet of horizontal distance beginning at the periphery of the horizontal zone extending to a height of 400 feet above the airport elevation b where an area is covered by more than one height limitation the more restrictive limitations shall prevail c nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the growth construction or maintenance of any tree or structure to a height up to 40 feet above the surface of the land app ii  4 use restrictions notwithstanding any other section of this article no use may be made of land within any zone established by this article in such a manner as to create electrical interference with radio communications between the airport and the aircraft to make it difficult for flyers to distinguish between airport lights and others to result in glare in the eyes of flyers using the airport to impair visibility in the vicinity of the airport or to otherwise endanger the landing taking off or maneuvering of aircraft app ii  5 nonconforming uses a would conform to the regulations prescribed in this article if such determination is in the affirmative the permit shall be granted 1 in the area lying within the limits of the horizontal zone and the approach zone 3 in the areas lying within the limits of the transition zones beyond the perimeter of the horizontal zone no permit shall be required for any tree or structure less than 50 feet of ii  9 article 6  airport land use zoning footnotes  5  state law reference municipal airport zoning law nmsa 197  3391633926 short title this article shall be known and may be cited as the farmington airport land use zoning  app iii  1 purpose the purpose and intent of the regulations adopted pursuant to this article shall be to encourage land use patterns for housing and other local needs that will separate uncontrollable noise sources from residential and other noisesensitive areas and to facilitate the orderly development of areas around airports by establishing regulations that must be met before such development will be permitted app iii  2 authority this article is adopted pursuant to nmsa 197  3211 et seq and nmsa 197  33916 et seq app iii  3 definitions the following words terms compatible use shall not be regarded as a use by right designated area means that area around an airport for which land use controls are needed to prevent development that would be sensitive to aircraft noise incompatible use means a use which shall not be permitted in the ldn zone where it is proposed ldn level means daynight average sound level as computed pursuant to federal aviation administration and environmental protection agency standards and procedures and arranged in contours on a map of airport area of influence ldn zone 2 means a designated area over which the noise level is between 65 and 75 ldn ldn zone 3 means a designated area over which the noise level exceeds ldn 75 app iii  4 applicability this article shall apply to development within the airport ldn zones 2 nonconforming structure any reuse reconstruction or replacement shall be deemed a new use and shall be subject to the applicable sections of this article app iii  6 establishment of airport zones a in this chapter sections 411 inclusive shall be known and may be cited as the farmington alarm system   81198 purpose the purpose of this chapter is to provide minimum standards and regulations applicable to burglar and holdup alarm systems alarm businesses alarm agents and alarm users as defined in this chapter this chapter shall not apply to fire alarms  81198 definitions for the purpose of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device which is designed primarily for the detection of an unauthorized entry into a building structure facility or of the commission of a robbery within a building structure or both  and which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when actuated which causes notification to be made directly or indirectly to the police department the representation in the ordinary course of business by a person selling or leasing a device that the device is sold or leased for the purpose of such detection shall create a presumption that the device is an alarm system for the purposes of this definition an alarm system shall not include 1 a device installed on a motor vehicle  2 devices which are not designed or used to register alarms that are audible visible or perceptible outside of the protected building structure or facility and which will not be transmitted or communicated to the communications center or police department  or devices installed in buildings structures or facilities controlled by the united states the state or any of its agencies institutions or political subdivisions  provided however that the provisions of section 4112 shall apply alarm system business means the business of any individual partnership corporation or other entity engaged in leasing maintaining servicing repairing altering replacing monitoring or installing any alarm system or in causing any alarm system to be leased maintained serviced repaired altered replaced monitored or installed in any building structure or facility alarm user means any person in control of any building structure or facility or portion thereof wherein an alarm system is maintained alarm user permit means a permit issued by the city allowing the operation of an alarm system within the city automatic dialing device means an alarm system which automatically sends over regular telephone lines by direct connection or otherwise a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation that the alarm system is designed to detect central station means that part of an alarm business which intercepts signals indicating the activation of an alarm device and which relays this information by live voice to the communications center or any police dispatch city manager means the city manager of the city or his designated representative direct line means a telephone line leading directly from a central station to the communication center or the police department that is for use only to report emergency signals on a persontoperson basis false alarm means the activation of any alarm system eliciting a response by the police department which was not the result of an emergency or threat of emergency of the kind for which the alarm system was designed to give notice unless the activation was a result of a power outage severe weather or interruption of telephone service hearing officer means the city manager or a person designated by the city manager to act as an impartial arbitrator at hearings related to the enforcement of this chapter interconnect means to connect an alarm system to a voicegrade telephone line either directly or mechanical device that utilizes a standard telephone for the purpose of using the telephone line to transmit an emergency message upon the activation of the alarm system local alarm system means a signaling system which when activated causes an audible andor visual signaling device to be activated in or on the premises within which the system is installed panic alarm means a device designed for the detection of a robbery holdup or the commission of an unlawful act within the premises protected by the alarm system and which may be intentionally activated by a person generates an inaudible signal to the communication center or the police department and may or may not generate an audible sound at the premises permit holder means the alarm user to whom an alarm user permit is issued permit year means beginning january 1 and emergency number is a primary trunk line  81198 alarm user permits a it shall be a violation of this chapter for any person to operate an alarm system without a valid alarm user permit b no person
